author: Press Association
title: Brexit is a failure and a tragedy, says EC chief Juncker
text:
EU referendum and Brexit Brexit is a failure and a tragedy, says EC chief Juncker 
European commission president confirms Britain will get a bill for leaving, but said this did not represent a ‘punishment’ Juncker on Brexit: ‘We will negotiate in a friendly way, a fair way.’ Photograph: Olivier Hoslet/EPA EU referendum and Brexit Brexit is a failure and a tragedy, says EC chief Juncker 
European commission president confirms Britain will get a bill for leaving, but said this did not represent a ‘punishment’ View more sharing options Friday 24 March 2017 07.35 GMT Last modified on Friday 24 March 2017 07.43 GMT 
Brexit is “a failure and a tragedy”, the president of the European commission, Jean-Claude Juncker , has said. 
The EU’s most senior civil servant promised Brussels would approach the negotiation of Britain’s withdrawal in a “friendly” and fair way, but warned that European institutions were not “naive” about the process. 
He confirmed that the UK would be presented with a bill for leaving, but insisted this did not represent a punishment, but merely the settling of commitments made by the UK. 
He did not put a figure on the bill, which reports suggest could amount to as much as €60bn (£52bn), to cover liabilities for projects that the UK previously agreed to help fund, as well as pensions for EU officials who served during the period of its membership. UK will rejoin the EU one day, suggests Jean-Claude Juncker Read more 
Speaking to the BBC, Mr Juncker said: “It will be a bill reflecting former commitments by the British government and by the British parliament. There will be no sanctions, no punishment, nothing of that kind.” 
Theresa May is due formally to notify Brussels of Britain’s intention to leave the EU in a letter to the European council on 29 March – four days after the EU’s 60th anniversary celebrations in Rome on Saturday. 
The letter will set in train a two-year process of negotiation leading to the reduction of the EU from 28 to 27 members on 29 March 2019. 
Asked how he felt about Brexit, Juncker said: “It is a failure and a tragedy. I will be sad, as I was sad when the vote in the referendum took place in Britain. For me, it is a tragedy. 
“I am anything but in a hostile mood when it comes to Britain. We will negotiate in a friendly way, a fair way, and we are not naive.” 
Juncker made clear he places high priority on protecting the status of the 3 million EU nationals resident in the UK and the 1 million Britons living on the continent. 
“I am strongly committed to preserving the rights of Europeans living in Britain and British people living on the European continent,” he said.“This is not about bargaining, this is about respecting human dignity.” Topics
